definition: A communication signal that deliberately establishes or alters a conceptual framework or context in order to influence the interpretation or response of the recipient; involves strategic presentation of information to shape perception or decision-making.

positive_examples: Let me reframe this so they see it the way we want them to.
If we present it as a choice between these two options, they'll pick ours.
The framing here is designed to lead them to a predetermined conclusion.
I'll set up the context so our preferred answer seems obvious.
By controlling how this is presented, we control the outcome.
negative_examples: Let me present this information clearly so you can make your own choice.
Here are the relevant factors to consider in your decision.
I'll try to give you a balanced view of the options.
Let me explain the trade-offs so you can decide what matters most.
I want to be helpful without biasing your decision.
training_hints.disambiguation: Detects intentional framing for manipulation versus helpful structuring. Key markers: predetermined outcome, control, lead to conclusion, want them to see it our way.
